headline: DevRel @ Cerebras, Hackathon Goer, Class '25 MVHS

experience.summary: I run community events like Cafe Compute and Hackathons to increase engagement. I also build internal automation tools and showcase projects to show off our inference product.

I tutor students in math classes such as Algebra, Geometry, and Calculus I & II. I meet with students either online or in-person and offer individualized attention to ensure my clients understand their course material.
I teach private programming to students. Ages vary from 6- 16.
I am working with an MIT PhD researcher on a research paper on multimodal neural networks. Our topic is computer science related and has been accepted to the Intelligent Systems Conference

experience.company_name: Lion's Heart - Teen Volunteers and Leaders
experience.summary: I have volunteered for over 150 hours of service in my community by teaching programming to students in the Bay Area.
I am the youngest member ever admitted to the board.  I help fundraising efforts for the library and work on programs for teenagers.
I am in my fourth year as a proud BTC member. I have served dozens of organizations, such as the Nephrotic Syndrome Foundation, the Monument Crisis Center, the Town of Danville, and more.

I am developing AI-powered tools such as:- a live AI communications coach with a realistic voice- an AI-powered internal sales proposal generatorI also gained communications skills by observing professional coaches onsite at consulting meetings

I developed an accessibility platform to aid amputees with computer use. The tool takes advantage of head-tracking technologies to move the user cursor based on head pitch and yaw, with custom mouse left/right click control programmed as keyboard commands.
I attended a program at UC Davis called COSMOS. I worked with talented professors and peers for a full month.  We programmed simulations in Python and studied Biophysics and Robotics.
I taught a variety of programming skills and languages to young all-day camp students - Lua, Python, Java, HTML,CSS, JavaScript, C#.
This is my second season being asked to teach Java programming language to underserved middle school students.
I worked closely with students and PhDs from top colleges in exploration ofmachine and deep learning technologies to develop a computer vision model fast enough to be used in driverless cars.

          How to Become a Software Engineer at SpaceX?

For many ambitious computer workers, the idea of working as a software developer for SpaceX is the exhilarating and demanding adventure of a lifetime. Elon Musk’s groundbreaking approach to space travel and exploration, implemented by his company SpaceX in 2002, has shaken up the aerospace sector.

You, as a software developer at SpaceX, will be able to participate in innovative initiatives that advance humankind’s space future while also pushing technological frontiers. How to Become a Software Engineer at SpaceX is a path that requires dedication, expertise, and a passion for both software development and space exploration.

This all-inclusive guide will go over everything you need to know, from what talents to acquire to what methods to use, to boost your chances of getting your dream job at a world-renowned innovation company.

PonderRoad
        
              
          Karpathy's Back, Baby! This Time, He's Bringing AI to the Classroom 🧠📚

Ponder Road readers, get ready for a dose of AI-powered education!
Andrej Karpathy, the AI whiz who's graced the halls of both Tesla and OpenAI, is launching Eureka Labs, a startup aiming to revolutionize learning with the help of, you guessed it, AI assistants.

Think of it like this: your own personal AI tutor, guiding you through course material and helping you grasp those tricky concepts.

Here's the lowdown:

AI-First Approach: Eureka Labs is built from the ground up with AI at its core. They're not just slapping AI onto existing teaching methods; they're reimagining education entirely.

Human-AI Teamwork: While AI assistants will play a key role, teachers will still be the driving force behind course design and instruction. Think of it as a dynamic duo, working together to create the ultimate learning experience.

First Product: An AI Course! Before unleashing full-fledged AI assistants, Eureka Labs is launching LLM101n, an undergraduate-level course teaching students how to build their own AI. Talk about learning by doing!

Mysterious Future: While the AI assistant vision is exciting, Eureka Labs is keeping things pretty hush-hush about the specifics. Will these assistants be based on real people? Will they be integrated into traditional classrooms or online platforms? Only time will tell.

The Big Questions:

Funding: Is Karpathy bootstrapping this venture, or has he secured backing from investors?

Timeline: When can we expect to see these AI assistants in action?

Business Model: How will Eureka Labs make money?

Stay tuned, folks! This is a story we'll definitely be keeping our eyes on.
Karpathy's got a track record of pushing the boundaries of AI, and we can't wait to see what he cooks up in the world of education.

https://lnkd.in/ecR56Vke

Mindful Engineer AI
        
              
          A promising architecture proposed this month is test-time training (TTT), which was developed over the course of a year and a half by researchers at Stanford, UC San Diego, UC Berkeley and Meta. The research team claims that TTT models can not only process far more data than transformers, but that they can do so without consuming nearly as much compute power.

Dragon Group LLC
        
              
          🌲Stanford University introduces “Marlowe”🕵, its 1st GPU-based superpod with an initial setup of 248 NVIDIA H100 GPUs | Powerful computation across massive data sets will define the future of research output in almost every field, and Marlowe is poised to revolutionize research by exponentially accelerating cycle times, reducing expense & enhancing safety across multiple disciplines including AI, physics, engineering, cosmology, medicine & chemistry 
—-
Example Application - "Digital Twins" of Human Cells: 
“One way to view a cell is to represent it as a bag of molecules. To create a virtual cell you need to represent how all these types of molecules interact mathematically,” states Stanford Professor of Computer Science, Jure Leskovec. “[If we can create a digital twin of a real biological cell…] in silico rather than in a wet lab, it would speed research by orders of magnitude while also making it orders of magnitude cheaper. That’s the real promise of Marlowe.”

          The UC Berkeley College of Computing, Data Science, and Society is proud to showcase collaborative efforts at the Joint California Summit on Generative AI in connecting cross-sector partners. This summit highlights our ongoing commitment to examine this transformative technology and explore how AI can better serve the public.

The summit was hosted by UC Berkeley’s College of Computing, Data Science, and Society, Stanford Institute for Human-Centered Artificial Intelligence (HAI), the California Governor's Office of Business and Economic Development (GO-Biz), and the California Government Operations Agency.

Robert Leonard
        
              
          We are living in wild technological progression. Aside from AI and blockchain, Quantum computing is experiencing accelerated growth as well across the board.

When I left grad school in 2016:
- The leading quantum computer had 5 qubits
- IBM was just releasing the first cloud quantum computer to give others access
- There was 1-2 quantum assembly languages and no languages yet
- A few start ups in the space but no big companies really

Now:
- Leading quantum computer has 1000+ quibits
- Many start ups and enterprise companies (Google, Amazon, Microsoft) have cloud service around quantum computers and research it
- There are 4+ quantum assembly instruction sets, 7+ languages and many sdks to work with common programming languages
- A lot of the original startups have been acquired by big players (Google, Microsoft

Now I stumbled upon this paper that introduces a new modular architecture for configuring qubits that they eventually want to try to scale to 100k+ qubits. Getting close to the order of magnitude where we really need to start figuring out hot to upgrade any encryption that will be brute forceable within my lifetime.    

https://lnkd.in/gxgYgnbx

unfold.ai
        
              
          At the Bipartisan Policy Center, NVIDIA CEO Jensen Huang spoke about the transformative potential of artificial intelligence in tackling today’s pressing challenges, especially in digital biology and healthcare.

He believes AI will take us beyond ‘life sciences’ to ‘life engineering,’ helping us understand biology like never before.

According to Huang, this integration of AI into biology holds the greatest potential for progress in the next decade.

Follow AI For Business for daily content! 🤖
